bibl.title: Military Orders regarding Philippi Caldas and Angel Bellingaghi, August 1, 1901

div1.p: These letters and supporting documents concern the request by Caldas and Bellingaghi to demonstrate their yellow fever serum. Included are translations from original Spanish letters and recommendations from Caldas and Tellez. Havard requests a medical commission to examine these claims. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Letter from Philippi Caldas to Hugh L. Scott, July 31, 1901
div1.p: Translate

Hlmo Señor Coronel Scott, Goberna
dor Interino de Cuba
Habana.

El año proximo pasado, mi colega y cola=
borador el Dr. Angel Bellingaghi, hizo experien=
cias con un suero anti-amarillo de mi
invencion, en Mexico y Vera- Cruz; obteniendo
los más halagueños resultados, conforme
oficialmente declaró el Consejo Superior
de Salubridad de Mexico, y los Dres
Parsons y Norton, directores del “Ame=
rican Hospital” de aquella ciudad.
Los resultados alcanzados por el Dr. Bellinga=
ghi, fueron identicos á los alcanzados
por mi el año anterior, en la ciudad
de Rio Janeiro; esto es, el 85 por % de
curas en la clinica hospitalaria.
Á la vez que tenian lugar estas
experiencias con el suero anti-ama=
rillo, yo llevaba estudios experimenta=
les y en anima-vili con una
vacuna activa, que confiere la
inmunidad contra la fiebre ama=
rilla.

Deseando demonstrar, de una ma=
nera evidente, ante el ilustrado
cuerpo medico de los Estados Unidos,
el poder curativo de mi suero anti-
amarillo y las propiedades inmu=
nizantes de mi vacuna activa,
resolvi de venir á Cuba,
juntamente con mi colaborador
el Dr. Bellingagli, á fin de
llevar á cabo dichas demon=
straciones.

Para ello, en homenaje al interes cien=
tifico y humanitario que la solucion de
tan grave asunto encierra, me permito
de solicitar su valioso apoyo, á fin
de que tengan lugar dichas demon=
straciones, bajo el más severo control
oficial.

Y si bien es verdad que actualmente
los pocos casos que hay de fiebre
amarilla, no pueden prestarse para
una larga experimentacion, por lo que
respecta al suero anti-amarillo;
sin embargo, cómo no escapará
á ser ilustrado criterio, pueden
hacerse rigorosas observaciones,
sirviendonos para ello de los mo=
squitos cómo un medio transmi=
sor de la infeccion; para probar
de una manera evidente, el poder inmu=
nizante que confiere mi vacuna contra
la fiebre amarilla.

Tengo el honor de presentarle
mis respetos y las protestas de
mi más distinguida considera=
cion, suscribiendome:
Dr. V. S. Glana
Cuba, 31 Julio de 1901.

div1.head: Letter from Philippi Caldas to Hugh L. Scott, July 31, 1901
div1.p: File under Caldas & Bellingaghi
FROM THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Translation.
Col. Scott, Acting Governor of Cuba.

Havana.
Last year, my colleague and collaborator, Dr. Angel Bellingaghi,
made experiments with an anti febrile (yellow) serum, invented by
me, in Mexico and Vera Cruz, obtaining the most flattering re-
sults, as officially declared by the Superior Board of Helath
of Mexico, and Doctors Parsons and Norton, Directors of the
American Hospital in that City.

While these experiments were being made with the serum in ques-
tion, I was making experimental studies with an active vaccine,
which gives immunity against yellow fever.

Desiring to demonstrate, in an evident manner, before the
learned Medical Professors of the United States, the curative
power of my serum as well as the immune properties of my active vac-
cine, I decided to come to Cuba, together with my collaborator
Dr. Bellingaghi, for the purpose of carrying into effect said
demonstrations.

For that purpose, in homage to the scientific and humane in-
terest which the solution of such a grave matter embraces, I
take the liberty to request your valuable cooperation, in order
that said demonstrations may be held under the most strict of-
ficial control.

Although it is true, that the present few cases
of yellow fever, will not permit an extensive experiment, in so far
as refers to the “anti-amarillo” serum; nevertheless you will
agree with me that careful observations may be made, using the
mosquitoes as a conveyor of the infection; to prove in an evi-
dent manner the power of immunity which my vaccine against yel-
low fever confers.

I have the honor to present my respects to you and
the protest of my most distinguished consideration.

closer.seg:
Havana, July 31st,1901.
P. S. Together with this I forward to you a letter from the
Vice Consul of Brazil.
(Fuentes.)

div1.head: Letter from Rafael Tellez to Hugh L. Scott, July 31, 1901
div1.opener:
Translation.
Vice-Consulate of the Republic if Brazil.
Havana, July 31st, 1901.
Sir:-
div1.p:
I take the liberty to introduce to you Dr. Philippi
Caldas of Rio Janeiro, who [unclear]comes to this Island with the object
of experimenting with a serum invented by him against yellow
fever.

Dr. Caldas comes highly recommended by the Consul General
of Brazil, in the United States, as a distinguished physician
of Bra zil; and in view of the great advantage that would be de-
rived by this Country if those experiments prove successful, I
beg to recommend him to your worthy consideration.

I have the honor to subscribe myself, with the utmost
consideration and respect.
div1.closer:
Rafael Tellez. Col. Scott, Military Governor of Cuba.
(Fuentes.)

div1.head: Military Orders regarding Philippi Caldas and Angel Bellingaghi, August 7, 1901
div1.p:
CIRCULAR LETTER, }
No. 59. }

HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT OF CUBA,
Havana, August 7, 1901.
A medical commission, to consist of:

Major Valery Havard, Surgeon, U. S. Army, Chief Sur-
geon of the Department;

The Physicians composing the Havana Yellow Fever
Board;

will meet at Las Animas Hospital in this city at 4 o'clock
P. M., August 9, 1901, or as soon thereafter as practicable,
for the purpose of examining into the propositions and
claims of Drs. Caldas and Bellingaghi, and submit, in con-
nection therewith, such recommendations as it may deem
best for the interest of science and of medicine.
BY COMMAND OF BRIGADIER GENERAL WOOD:

H. L. SCOTT,
Captain 7th Cavalry,
Adjutant General.
